988 will help enhance public safety, deliver better outcomes for community members, and reduce strain on the relationship between police officers and the people they are sworn to serve. This lifeline is a great resource for our community and our country.

Members of our community will be able to call 988 if they are witnessing or experiencing a mental health crisis. 988 will work in conjunction with 911 to ensure that trained professionals - such as social workers, paramedics, and peer support counselors - respond to the call.

I wrote an op-ed for the @seattletimes about the need to reform police response and the success that 911 diversion programs could bring to communities across the country:
https://www.seattletimes.com/opinion/specialized-unarmed-911-response-teams-can-best-help-people-in-crisis/

That's why I authored the 911 Diversion to Unarmed Personnel Act, which would provide funding for unarmed crisis response teams that divert nonviolent 911 calls to specialized service providers who are better equipped to handle these calls.

1 in every 10 calls for police response involves a person suffering from a mental illness, and in most places around the U.S. operators have no choice but to deploy police officers to every scene, regardless of whether they are equipped or trained to handle these situations.

I will first join @SecBecerra, @PattyMurray, @RepJayapal, and @RepKimSchrieron a tour of Crisis Connections, which will be a key partner in the transition to the 988 National Suicide Prevention Lifeline.

Today, I'm pleased to welcome @SecBecerra to Washington State for a stop on the National Tour to Strengthen Mental Health to hear directly from Americans in our region about the mental health and wellness challenges they‚Äôre facing right now.

We must stand firm in our resolve to bolster our nation‚Äôs cyber resilience across local, state, and federal levels and throughout each sector of our economy. Our national security and economic stability depend on it. (7/7)

More here‚¨áÔ∏è https://garbarino.house.gov/issues/cybersecurity

I'm looking forward to continuing this important work. With the increasingly complex threats posed by Russia, the United States cannot afford to shy away from defending ourselves from malign foreign actors. (6/7)

By equipping @CISAgov with information about cyber incidents, the federal government can work hand-in-hand with industry to mitigate the impacts of events like Colonial and prevent cascading effects across all 16 critical infrastructure sectors. (5/7)

I have also been working with my colleagues on @HomelandGOP to enhance @CISAgov's operational visibility into lifeline sector cyber vulnerabilities.

I am immensely proud to have co-led the Cyber Incident Reporting for Critical Infrastructure Act of 2021. (4/7)

.@HomelandGOP, and our cyber subcommittee, has held numerous hearings to analyze the impact of the Colonial Pipeline attack and how government can work more closely with the private sector to prevent foreign adversaries from attacking our most critical infrastructure. (3/7)

Since the attack, I have been working diligently to make my constituents and all Americans aware of the services offered by @CISAgov to protect themselves and their organizations from cyber adversaries at no cost. (2/7) 

https://www.cisa.gov/

It's been a year since the Colonial Pipeline ransomware attack which impacted gas supply along the east coast.

It was a wake up call that we must increase cyber resilience & mitigation measures to protect critical lifeline sectors like energy, water, & financial services. (1/7)
